item.title: Covid-19: Up to 75% of new UK cases could be Indian variant - Matt Hancock
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock says it is "critical" to monitor the link between cases and hospitalisations.

item.title: Covid-19: Matt Hancock defends care home action after Cummings' claims
item.description: He is accused of lying about ensuring testing for those discharged from hospitals to care homes.

item.title: Covid: Live music events to return in Wales
item.description: Venues will need to limit groups to a maximum of six people from six households.

item.title: Belarus: Russia blocks some flights for avoiding its ally
item.description: Air France and Austrian Airlines Moscow routes are stopped as Russia rejects their new flight plans.

item.title: Eastbourne fire: Three men guilty over house fire murders of mum and son
item.description: Gina Ingles and four-year-old Milo Ingles-Bailey died in a fire after a row over drugs debts.

item.title: Lisa Shaw: Vaccine role in BBC presenter's death to be probed
item.description: Lisa Shaw's family say the 44-year-old fell seriously ill days after having the AstraZeneca jab.

item.title: Arlene Foster awarded £125k damages in Dr Christian Jessen libel case
item.description: A judge rules an unfounded tweet by Dr Christian Jessen about an alleged extra-marital affair was "outrageous".

item.title: New dark matter map reveals cosmic mystery
item.description: The most detailed map of dark matter in the Universe is puzzling physicists.

item.title: Forced adoptions to be investigated by Parliament
item.description: MPs and Lords will examine the issue, estimated to have affected 250,000 unmarried women over 30 years.

item.title: San Jose shooting: Victims named after rail employee kills nine
item.description: The death toll has risen to nine after the shooting in the Californian city of San Jose.

item.title: County lines: The search for vulnerable children
item.description: The BBC's Angus Crawford joins police as they look for vulnerable young people involved in county lines.

item.title: Airbnb extends worldwide party ban until end of summer
item.description: The online rental platform said on Thursday it was "in the best interest of public health".

item.title: Angry, upset, relieved - Covid bereaved families on Cummings claims
item.description: After Dominic Cummings' testimony on Wednesday, some bereaved by the pandemic are asking: what if?

item.title: Friends reunion: 10 of the best moments
item.description: The six stars have reunited for a new televised special, 17 years after Friends drew to a close.

item.title: Friends cast 'has extraordinary chemistry'
item.description: But Warren Littlefield, who commissioned Friends, says it would be hard to make the show today.

item.title: Agency worker's LinkedIn rant about 'picky' staff leads to job offers
item.description: Lee Moore's post about fellow agency staff is seen by more than four million people.

item.title: Super 'blood' Moon treats stargazers around the world
item.description: Two rare celestial events have coincided as the Moon appears larger during a lunar eclipse.

item.title: In pictures: Prince William and Kate visit Scotland
item.description: The Earl and Countess of Strathearn are attending a series of events during their trip north of the border.

item.title: Mountain biker Bienvenido Aguado lands record 100ft front flip
item.description: Spanish rider Bienvenido Aguado lands what is believed to be the longest dirt-to-dirt front flip on record.

item.title: Nexta: The journalists taking on Belarus’ regime
item.description: The BBC visits the colleagues of Roman Protasevich, the journalist arrested off the diverted Ryan Air flight.

item.title: Weather in the UK: Will the wetter weather get better?
item.description: The past few weeks have been particularly rainy in the UK - with Wales even having the wettest May on record.

item.title: India YouTuber arrested for 'flying' dog with helium balloons
item.description: He tied helium balloons to his dog and attempted to "fly" the pet to make a viral video.

item.title: North Yorkshire Police find nine people in uninsured car
item.description: Two female passengers crawled out of the boot during the traffic stop in North Yorkshire.

item.title: Does the UK have highest Covid death toll in Europe?
item.description: The total is the largest but for deaths per 100,000 people the UK is no longer top.

item.title: Covid origin: Why the Wuhan lab-leak theory is being taken seriously
item.description: The claim Covid-19 may have leaked from a Chinese laboratory is gaining traction. Here's what we know.

item.title: Will tennis star Naomi Osaka's media silence prompt change?
item.description: Naomi Osaka is not speaking to the media at the French Open to protect her mental health - will her move change anything?

item.title: Covid vaccination rollout: How is Wales leading the UK and the world?
item.description: It is quite the contrast with January, when questions were being asked about Wales' slow start.

item.title: Belarus: I'm ready to beg for help, says mother of detained woman
item.description: The mother of Sofia Sapega, who was arrested when her flight was grounded in Minsk, speaks to the BBC.

item.title: Tulsa massacre: The search for victims, 100 years on
item.description: Decades after white mobs razed an affluent black neighbourhood the search for bodies goes on.

item.title: 'I pictured my son's drowning on my charity swim'
item.description: A woman, whose son drowned on holiday, tells how the open water challenge stirred up panic attacks and flashbacks.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: How rising patient numbers threaten to overwhelm GPs
item.description: Patients are struggling to get appointments as GPs report a surge in appointments being booked.

item.title: The uncertain future of Britain's offices
item.description: UK firms' offices are undergoing radical shifts as firms allow staff to continue working from home.

item.title: Coronavirus: What guidance did care homes get from the government?
item.description: Boris Johnson says "too many care homes didn't really follow the procedures", so what was the coronavirus guidance given to them?

item.title: Cummings' claims fact-checked
item.description: Boris Johnson's former chief adviser made a series of claims and allegations about the government's response to the pandemic.

item.title: Mozambique Palma attack: 'I had to pay a bribe to flee'
item.description: Aid agencies have been barred from parts of Mozambique, leading to fears of a humanitarian emergency.

item.title: 'Fortress Australia': Why calls to open up borders are meeting resistance
item.description: Many Australians are loath to relax border controls despite experts warning of the harms of isolation.

item.title: Tottenham make contact with former boss Pochettino
item.description: Tottenham contact Mauricio Pochettino, who managed them from 2014 to 2019, about a return to the club.

item.title: Lawro's predictions: Man City v Chelsea - Champions League final special with Noel Gallagher and Dot Major
item.description: BBC football expert Mark Lawrenson takes on Noel Gallagher and Dot Major to predict whether Manchester City or Chelsea will win the Champions League final.

item.title: Picking GB Olympic squad 'the hardest decision I ever made' - Riise
item.description: Head coach Hege Riise says selecting the players to represent Great Britain at this summer's Olympic Games was "the hardest decision I ever made".

item.title: Hameed has 'come back strong' to earn England recall - Giles
item.description: Batsman Haseeb Hameed has "come back strong" to earn an England recall, according to Ashley Giles.

item.title: Nadal, Djokovic & Federer in same half of French Open draw
item.description: Defending champion Rafael Nadal could meet Novak Djokovic in the French Open semi-finals after the pair land in the same half of the men's draw.

item.title: England kick off against Fiji - 2021 Rugby World Cup fixtures schedule released
item.description: England will open their Rugby World Cup campaign next year against debutants Fiji at Eden Park in New Zealand.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Watch five great goals from Team GB's football stars
item.description: Before Tokyo 2020, watch five great goals from Great Britain's football stars including Chelsea's Fran Kirby and Manchester City's Caroline Weir.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can now have the vaccine in Wales and Northern Ireland, while over-30s can get it in England and Scotland.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Children tell of neglect, filth and fear in US asylum camps
item.description: The BBC has uncovered allegations of cold temperatures, sickness, lice and abuse, through a series of interviews with children and staff at US detention camps for children.

item.title: Rafael Nadal: The 'tough love' that shaped a 20-time Grand Slam champion
item.description: From 'scaredy cat' to a 'raging bull', Rafael Nadal's transformation into a true tennis great has a lot to do with one man in particular.

item.title: Martin Bashir inquiry: Diana, the reporter and the BBC
item.description: The full story of how the BBC's Martin Bashir got his 1995 interview with Princess Diana - and what happened next.
